docs.lead_paragraph: Back pain is costing the United States billions of dollars a year in lost workdays and compensation, and most cases are caused by on-the-job injuries, according to researchers. But there are ways to reduce this rate, including giving workers some control over their jobs and encouraging them to get fit, another team of researchers said.

headline.main: Back Pain Takes Its Toll on Work Force

docs.abstract: Research on back pain, which costs US billions of dollars a year in lost work days and compensation, suggests giving workers some control over their tasks, and encouraging fitness; Dr How-Ran Guo and colleagues at National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health report on study (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The first of July marks the day that hospitals open their doors to the new crop of interns, a number of them clutching dog-eared copies of a pot-boiler novel called ''The House of God.'' Published 21 years ago, the book chronicles a year in the life of an intern training at one of the best hospitals in the country, which the author will not identify. Though the book is virtually unknown outside the health care field, despite an introduction by John Updike, it is passed from one intern to the next and has sold more than two million copies.

headline.main: Medicine's Steamy Side, for and About Interns

docs.abstract: The House of God, book little known outside medical schools, chronicles year in life of an intern in lurid detail, replete with medical errors and steamy sex with voluptuous nurses; Dr Stephen Bergman wrote novel 21 years ago under pen name Samuel Shem, and young doctors say it is still relevant; jacket photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A man facing prostate cancer can find himself lost in a forest of contradictory treatment options even before the final diagnosis is in. To help negotiate the often uncharted terrain, the American Cancer Society and the National Comprehensive Cancer Network, a coalition of 17 top cancer centers, have issued diagnostic and treatment guidelines based on how prostate cancer is most commonly treated and diagnosed today.

headline.main: Navigating the Options for Prostate Cancer

docs.abstract: American Cancer Society and National Comprehensive Cancer Network, coalition of 17 cancer centers, issue diagnostic and treatment guidelines to help men decide on prostate cancer treatment (S)
docs.snippet: A man facing prostate cancer can find himself lost in a forest of contradictory treatment options even before the final diagnosis is in.     To help negotiate the often uncharted terrain, the American Cancer Society and the National Comprehensive...

docs.lead_paragraph: This is no time to get complacent about Lyme disease, the most common tick-borne illness in the country. Although the Food and Drug Administration licensed the first Lyme disease vaccine for people in December, we continue to have problems preventing this usually treatable but sometimes devastating bacterial disease. The three-dose vaccine is effective but not perfect, and disease-bearing ticks are expected to be unusually abundant this year. Even if fully vaccinated, everyone who ventures outdoors in areas where ticks carrying the Lyme bacteria are likely to be present is at risk of contracting the disease and would be wise to observe all the usual precautions about preventing tick bites. These bacteria, spirochetes with the scientific name Borrelia burgdorferi, are typically carried by tiny deer ticks that feed on white-footed mice and lizards as well as deer, people and pets.

headline.main: Finding the Right Tactics to Prevent Lyme Disease

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column urges continued vigilance against Lyme disease; warns that new vaccine is not perfect and disease-bearing ticks are expected to be unusually abundant this year; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many women suffering from urinary tract infections may be able to skip a trip to the doctor's office, be safely diagnosed and receive prescriptions by telephone, according to a study in the current issue of The American Journal of Medicine. Almost half of all American women are plagued by uncomplicated urinary tract infections, also known as cystitis. The irritating symptoms include an urge to urinate frequently, burning sensations and sometimes bleeding during urination. The disorder is often diagnosed with a urine test and treated with antibiotics.

headline.main: A Cure as Close as the Nearest Phone

docs.abstract: Telephone diagnosis for urinary tract infections, without usual urine test, proves effective in test (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration has proposed that warning labels be put on eggs to alert consumers to the possible serious illnesses, including salmonella poisoning, that eggs can cause. ''Eggs are a good source of protein and can be a healthy and economical contribution to a well-balanced diet,'' Dr. Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said. ''However, they need proper handling or they could potentially be the source of food-borne illness.''

headline.main: Administration Calls for Warning Labels on Eggs

docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Department proposes warning labels on eggs about salmonella poisoning and other possible illnesses; Agriculture Department and FDA order all eggs and egg products to be refrigerated at 45 degrees or below; GAO report also suggests consolidating egg safety, now handled by four agencies (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The last time I hopped around in an exercise class, George Bush was in the White House and Spandex ruled. These exercise classes -- aerobics, step, jazz aerobics, jazz step, jazz aerobics step -- were excruciatingly repetitive and boring. I abandoned them and their Paula Abdul music mixes with glee when I met my (Stair)master and, on alternate days, took to the streets running.
docs.abstract: Andrea Higbie article on taking kickboxing lessons for exercise and self-protection; drawings (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Several Earth-like planets, created billions of years ago during the formation of our solar system, may be wandering in deep space harboring conditions that could sustain some form of life, according to a new theory proposed by a prominent planetary scientist. These orphan worlds, ejected from the solar system by gravitational forces during its tumultuous beginnings, may have retained atmospheres rich in molecular hydrogen even as they were flung into the dark void of interstellar space, said Dr. David J. Stevenson, a professor of planetary science at the California Institute of Technology.

headline.main: Sunless, Airless, And Full Of Life?

docs.abstract: Dr David J Stevenson proposes theory that several Earth-like planets, created billions of years ago and ejected from our solar system by gravitational forces, may be 'wandering' in deep space, harboring conditions that could sustain some form of life; speculates that rogue planets may have retained atmospheres rich in molecular hydrogen, which could trap enough volcanic heat to sustain water oceans and some simple life forms (M)
docs.snippet: Several Earth-like planets, created billions of years ago during the formation of our solar system, may be wandering in deep space harboring conditions that could sustain some form of life, according to a new theory proposed by a prominent planetary...

docs.lead_paragraph: Alarmed by what they see as the potential for mishaps with patients taking herbal remedies for everything from depression to memory loss, anesthesiologists have begun urging people to stop taking the herbs and supplements before having surgery. Doctors say there is growing evidence that substances like St. John's wort and ginkgo biloba may have dangerous interactions with the drugs used to anesthetize patients during surgery. Although hard scientific evidence of a problem is lacking, they say, anecdotal reports from hospitals suggest that herbal remedies may be putting some surgery patients at serious risk.

headline.main: A Warning Not to Mix Surgery And Herbs

docs.abstract: American Society of Anesthesiologists warns people to stop taking herbs and supplements before having surgery, because substances like St John's wort and ginkgo biloba may have dangerous interactions with anesthetics; doctors add suspicions about feverfew and ginseng; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Alarmed by what they see as the potential for mishaps with patients taking herbal remedies for everything from depression to memory loss, anesthesiologists have begun urging people to stop taking the herbs and supplements before having surgery.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: A generation ago, when people took prescriptions to the local drugstore, there was a good chance that the pharmacist, rather than just pulling a prepackaged item off the shelf, would actually mix and measure ingredients to fill capsules or create ointments or cough syrup. Although that practice, ''compounding,'' has largely given way to ready-made products, it is still used to prepare individual prescriptions for people who need something not commercially available. They may be allergic to a preservative or dye in a certain medication, for instance, or need a dose or a drug mixture that is not mass-produced.

headline.main: New Fight Over the Old Art of Drug Compounding

docs.abstract: Compounding of drugs, commonly done by pharmacists in past, has largely been replaced by ready-products, but some drugstores still specialize in practice, which exists in gray zone of FDA regulation; controversy erupts as advocates for people with hepatitis C advise that Fisher's Specialty Pharmacy Services in Pittsburgh can compound expensive drug Ribavirin from bulk powder, when Schering-Plough's patent runs out this month (M)
